original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
short: Some managers try to make feedback easier to hear by starting and ending with positive comments around any criticism – like a sandwich. But if this happens often, people may think the positive comments aren’t sincere and don’t mean much. It’s better to give positive feedback to really show someone what they’re doing well and encourage them to keep it up, not just to soften bad news.
descr:

But if this happens all the time, people might think the nice things aren’t real – they might think you’re just trying to make the criticism sound better. It’s better to give praise when someone does something well, to help them keep doing it and feel good about their work, not just to soften bad news.

It’s better to give good news to encourage people when they do well, and to help them improve when they need to. Don't just use good news to soften bad news. To understand how we learned to use complex language, we need to study the human brain and how it differs from animal brains. It’s not just about size, but also what our brains can *do*, and *when* these abilities developed.

Unfortunately, it’s hard to find evidence. Old tools don’t tell us about the language our ancestors used. However, we can look at the bones of early humans – the mouth, throat and tongue have changed over time. 

Around 100,000 years ago, humans could make complicated sounds. Before that, scientists aren’t sure if early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.
descr:

Around 100,000 years ago, humans could make lots of different sounds. Before that time, scientists who study how living things change over time (**evolutionary biologists**) can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to talk to each other.
